content: "Section 1 discusses leases, easements, and rights-of-way on the Outer Continental Shelf." Section 8 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to allow for royalty suspension provisions for oil and natural gas leases issued during specific Gulf of Mexico lease sales. The price thresholds for royalty suspension are set at $34.73 per barrel for oil and $4.34 per million Btu for natural gas (2005 dollars), with adjustments made annually after 2005. After 2005, price thresholds for royalty suspension volumes will be adjusted annually based on changes in the implicit price deflator for the gross domestic product. New thresholds will apply to any royalty suspension volumes granted by the Secretary, with amended leases imposing the new thresholds starting October 1, 2006. Additionally, a conservation of resources fee of $9 per barrel for oil and $1.25 per million Btu for gas will be established for producing leases. A conservation of resources fee will be established at $9 per barrel for oil and $1.25 per million Btu for gas. The fee will only apply to leases with deep water royalty relief when prices exceed certain thresholds. The fee will be effective for production starting on or after October 1, 2006. The Coastal Impact Assistance Program is established under Section 2. Section 31(b) of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to address royalty revenues from certain leases issued with deep water royalty relief in the Central or Western Gulf of Mexico. The Secretary of the Treasury is required to deposit the royalty revenues in a specified manner. The amendment to Section 31(b) of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act requires royalty revenues from certain leases with deep water royalty relief in the Gulf of Mexico to be deposited in a special account for disbursement to Gulf producing States and coastal political subdivisions. Any remaining royalty revenues are to be used for deficit reduction. The amendment to Section 31(b) of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act specifies the determination of qualified outer Continental Shelf revenues for fiscal years 2011 through 2016 based on revenues received in fiscal year 2010. SEC. 3. SENSE OF THE CONGRESS TO BUY AND BUILD AMERICAN. The Congress intends for this Act to promote American industrial growth and create jobs by utilizing American workforce talents for developing affordable energy from the Outer Continental Shelf. Additionally, it aims to encourage the use of American technology and manufacturing in the Outer Continental Shelf operations to benefit U.S. workers with good jobs and careers.
